Abstract:
The study of the pathophysiology of obesity is an important area of research. Studies have shown that obese individuals have a higher risk of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes (T2D) compared to lean individuals. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the changes in metabolic markers in obese individuals after bariatric surgery and investigate whether these changes were influenced by the type of bariatric procedure performed. This quasi‐experimental study recruited obese individuals who underwent bariatric surgery between August 2018 and May 2019. 49 subjects were included, of which 26 received Roux‐en‐Y gastric bypass (RYGB), and 23 received sleeve gastrectomy (SG). Metabolic markers including Body Mass Index (BMI), lipid profile, fasting blood glucose (FBG), and homeostatic model assessment of insulin resistance (HOMA‐IR) were measured before and after surgery. Data were analyzed using paired t‐test and the chi‐square test. A p‐value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.
